author: thehacktivist
content: Well, that's a full server spam

author: odyslam
content: Hey everyone, I was wondering if anyone runs. full-node or miner. I have a question regarding the way that you are monitoring the server. I run a geth locally and access the metrics at `debug/metrics/prometheus`, but I am unsure what metrics are important and how to organize them in charts. Is monitoring even a problem full-node/miners people have?

author: krustybunkers
content: I think there are different schools of thought on the need for monitoring. Some people set up grafana dashboards using prometheus as the datasource for validator metrics. Others don't see the need, go in and just prune geth every once in awhile. I think everyone recommends tracking your validator on beaconcha.in

author: krustybunkers
content: Sorry! Just realized you were talking about miners and not validators. On that front, i can't really help

author: odyslam
content: My question actually stems from the fact that during the day I am DevRel at netdata, which is an opensource monitoring agent, and I was wondering whether an integration would make sense. To be more exact, it's more a matter of organizing the metrics into charts that produce value for the user.

author: odyslam
content: Well, validators as well

author: odyslam
content: I am just looking for ways to contribute from my position. It's interesting that the issue of monitoring is more obscure than I would expect

author: krustybunkers
content: Ah, in that case, pretty much everyone I've talked to uses the prometheus -> grafana process. If you search for "ethereum grafana dashboard", there are a few github projects that may give you some inspiration.

author: odyslam
content: Thanks Krusty!

author: alexssd7fp
content: No one uses L2

author: alexssd7fp
content: So miners end up withdrawing funds to the mainnet anyway

author: alexssd7fp
content: ethermine integrated l2 just because they will not be able to "cover" post-1559 tx fees

author: trent_vanepps
content:
this may have been the case a year ago, but I'd suggest you look into the existing finance ecosystem on Polygon. 

even if people only get 6 months of payouts on an L2 and then withdraw to mainnet that would be a huge improvement

author: alexssd7fp
content: are you affiliated with matic?

author: alexssd7fp
content: because you sound like you are üòÖ

author: alexssd7fp
content: Anyways

author: alexssd7fp
content: We did a research internally and came up with the decision that using L2 now will not make a significant improvement

author: fliguy.eth
content: really no one uses L2 in Polygon, crazy if you think that, its going crazy atm

author: trent_vanepps
content:
no, I work for the EF. 

even if miners only use the L2 for consolidating intermittent payments (not finance apps), it would be a significant improvement to the current state. no more .1 ETH minimums

anyways
I'd encourage you to look into this again, it may be worthwhile.

author: alexssd7fp
content:
> even if miners only use the L2 for consolidating intermittent payments (not finance apps), it would be a significant improvement to the current state. no more .1 ETH minimums
on our pool minimum is .01 ETH, but unlike on any other mining pool, here the miner pays the transaction fee

author: alexssd7fp
content: hahaha

author: alexssd7fp
content: w/ how we call self-mining, miners are forced to pay an indirect tax to cover pool payouts that depending on the block reward, ranges from 3-6%

author: alexssd7fp
content: on our pool people decide what fees to pay on their own
